text: Patient: Yes, I know, my family doctor, same thing. Doctor: Yeah. So, I think you have to sign signature of patient here, right here. Patient: Okay Alright. Doctor: So use that and then date it. That’s right. Family Member: If he does the chemo or radium Doctor: Yeah Family Member: and then a trial opens up does he just jump to the trial? Doctor: No. Oh, you got to date it, Sorry. Patient: Oh, I’m sorry. Doctor: I can’t even date it for you. It has to be you. Yeah. Um, Uh, If it’s working we don’t bail out, only if it’s not working, but we will have, you know, the trials are like a moving target so if there’s something that pops up and I think that you would benefit then yes, we would make that opportunity. So, I’m always aware of what’s up here which is why I pulled you guys back to say there’s nothing here that is anything other than chemo but now as we’re thinking about this I’ll know, you know, by this week, okay, that’s a lie because this is Thursday, Family Member: It’s Thursday Doctor: by next week, what two trials make sense based on you know what’s happening. You know, the hard part about those chemo trials is there is a group that only gets the chemo. I like that because everybody gets chemo.

text: Patient: I did. Doctor: Yeah, so it’s- Patient: Yeah, I, I, when they, they said I had phlebotomy, I asked if it was fasting, and they said “No.” So, I, uh, ate breakfast. Doctor: And your PSA today is twenty-two. Patient: Ouch. Doctor: That’s all good. And your testosterone is (pause6sec) Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck?

text: Family Member: …than chemo, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Does any others have xxx]? Doctor: I think and since his cancer has shown us over the years that it was very sensitive to hormonal therapies, I would advocate doing that – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - unless I see you know big huge lymph nodes or some xxx] in there that I’m majorly concerned about. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The other option again for lymph nodes of a specific size and the size limitation is more because one of the studies we have requires the smallest size of the lymph node to be one point five centimeter or higher. And that is uh a combination of a medication called Cabozantinib with an immune therapy. So that combination I think I would strongly recommend looking at if you have enough disease that needs treatment. Obviously if there’s… Patient: Are you gonna be able to find that out today? Doctor: I’m hoping to, yes. So that’s why I said let’s try and get some preliminary information on your CAT scans because that is going to be the key decision maker. Patient: More so than a bone? Doctor: I think the bone scan the problem is your report compared it to I don’t know a scan done years ago, because in between all the bone scans you had were here, they were not up there…

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation? Doctor: So we actually prefer it because we actually know how to treat your whole body systemically with all these medicines from the chemist. (whistle noise) Patient: Right. Doctor: With these medicines, but we also, and it also gives you more time to heal. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: From the surgery, which is better for you as far as long-term side effects. Family Member: Uh hum. Okay.

text: Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works.

text: Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down. Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get --

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
